answers: x divided by log of x [or x over log x; accept “ln” or “logarithm” or “natural logarithm” instead of “log”]
parts: Name this algorithm that works by iteratively labeling all multiples of primes as composite and thereafter crossing them out which leaves only the prime numbers behind.

Calculating the time complexity of the Sieve of Eratosthenes relies on summing this series over the prime numbers. This series equals one plus one-half plus one-third plus one-fourth and so on, and it slowly diverges.
The prime number theorem states that, asymptotically, the prime counting function of x approximately equals this function of x.

answers: People of the Book [or People of the Scripture; or Ahl al-Kitab; prompt on Ahl al-Dhimmi]
Ahl al-Bayt [prompt on Family of the House with “can you give the Arabic term?”]
parts: In early Islamic history, Christians, Jews, and Sabians were known as the “people of” this thing because they adhered to monotheistic scriptures.
This overarching term refers to the Muslim community as a whole, regardless of national or ancestral background.

In Shia Islam, this term refers to relatives of Muhammad and some infallible imams, while to Sunnis it only refers to some members of Muhammad’s family. In English, it roughly translates to “People of the House.”
Name this standard of judicial review. To pass this standard, laws must be narrowly tailored to meet a compelling government interest while employing the least restrictive means.
This 1944 Supreme Court decision concerning interned Japanese-Americans during World War II was the first case to withstand strict scrutiny.
This Chief Justice authored Footnote Four and the Carolene Products opinion, and addressed jurisdiction over unlawful combatants in Ex Parte Quirin.
Name this book that ends with the death of the protagonist when she is hit by a yellow Mercedes immediately after visiting a fortune teller.
This woman hits and kills Myrtle while driving a yellow car that belongs to someone who is later shot for the accident in a novel by F. Scott Fitzgerald.

Although it is not used to hit anyone, a yellow pickup truck is a prized possession in this novel. After the title character takes it, Maureen waits outside in the rain naked until she sees the truck return.
Name this contrapuntal form in which each voice states a subject in turn. J.S. Bach paired a spooky toccata in D minor with a piece in this form.
This Canadian pianist turned the rules of writing fugue into lyrics in his vocal piece So You Want to Write a Fugue? His career took off with a 1955 recording of Bach’s Goldberg Variations.

Gould warned that diminution combined with this technique, usually employed towards the end of a fugue, was an “obvious solution.” This Italian term refers to starting the answer in one voice before the previous voice has finished the subject, so they overlap.

answers: Pope Pius IX [or Giovanni Maria Mastai Ferretti]
parts: Name this Pope who restored a Roman Catholic diocesan (“DYE-oh-SEE-sin”) hierarchy to England in the 1850 bull Universalis Ecclesiae. This pope convened the First Vatican Council and promulgated the dogma of the Immaculate Conception.

Though he had introduced the repeal of the discriminatory Test Acts, this Prime Minister responded to the papal bull by banning the use of the new Catholic titles. This Whig championed the 1832 Reform Act under Lord Grey.

British public opinion also turned on this High Church movement led by John Henry Newman, whose leaders had mostly converted to Catholicism. This movement is named for its association with a university that traditionally rivals Cambridge.

answers: trust [accept mistrust; accept trust versus mistrust]
John Bowlby [or Edward John Mostyn Bowlby]
parts: This Swiss psychologist proposed that children proceed through sensorimotor, preoperational, concrete operational, and formal operational stages.

Psychologist Erik Erikson envisioned developmental stages as progressing through various conflicts. In his model, the first stage of development—from ages 0 to 1.5—has a basic virtue of hope and a psychosocial crisis defined by the presence or absence of this concept.
According to this British psychologist's attachment theory, infants who experience maternal deprivation would undergo separation anxiety.
Name this city. Karim leaves the suburbs to come here while his father hosts guru sessions in Hanif Kureishi's The Buddha of Suburbia.
Samad Iqbal immigrates from Bangladesh to London after World War II and becomes friends with Archie Jones in this author's novel White Teeth.

In this book by Monica Ali named for a Bengali district in London, Nazneen has to scrape the corns off her husband Chanu's feet, writes to her sister Hasina in Bangladesh, and has an affair with Karim.
Name this anti-inflammatory drug commonly used for fever and mild aches. 81 milligrams of this drug per day is used as primary prevention against cardiovascular events.
NSAIDs like aspirin target COX-1, inhibiting the formation of these signaling molecules made from cell membrane lipids that are involved in smooth muscle contraction.
Aspirin also modifies COX-2, inhibiting the synthesis of prostaglandins and these compounds which bind platelets together. Their A2 variety is released by activated platelets.

answers: Nosferatu: A Symphony of Horror [or Nosferatu, eine Symphonie des Grauens]
parts: Name this film directed by F.W. Murnau which stars Max Schreck as Orlok, who pursues the real estate agent Thomas Hutter.
Nosferatu was an unauthorized adaptation of this novel by Bram Stoker. Bela Lugosi starred as the title character in Tod Browning’s 1931 film based on it.

Horror films and other stylized genres typically used a lighting setup with a high “ratio” of intensity for the key light relative to this other type of light. A traditional three-point setup consists of a key light, a back light, and one of these.

Name this former Minister of Defense who leads the Yisrael Beitenu party. This man’s insistence on removing the draft exemptions for the ultra-Orthodox led to another round of Israeli elections in September 2019.
This current Prime Minister has been unable to hold Yisrael Beitenu and ultra-Orthodox parties in the same coalition, preventing him from obtaining a majority in the Knesset (“kuh-NESS-it”).

Lieberman has urged for a unity government with Netanyahu’s Likud and this alliance, which now holds the most seats in the Knesset. This party’s leader Benny Gantz has refused to partner with Likud as long as Netanyahu leads it.

answers: Bacchus [or Dionysus; or The Triumph of Bacchus]
parts: Name these artists. The earlier artist’s self portrait with the red cross of the Order of Santiago inspired the later artist to paint a self-portrait over a portrait of his wife Suzanne, who shared modeling duties with Victorine Meurent.

In a letter to Henri-Fantin Latour, Manet described being dazzled by this painting, which contains that Velazquez self-portrait. This group portrait of the Spanish court centers on the Infanta Margaret Theresa.

The background of Manet’s Portrait of Emile Zola features a Goya reproduction of a Velázquez painting of this god. That rowdy group portrait shows this god’s “triumph” as he crowns a man with a wreath.

This Harvard chemist was the first to achieve quinine total synthesis along with William Doering. This father of total synthesis names a set of rules for predicting the stereochemistry of pericyclic reactions with Roald Hoffmann.

It is commonly believed that Woodward incorporated this chemist’s method in synthesizing enantiopure quinotoxine for his synthesis. Along with Cahn and Ingold, this man co-names a set of rules for naming stereoisomers.

The final step of Prelog’s synthesis involved Claisen reaction, which is this type of molecular addition reaction that generates water. This type of reaction is thus the reverse of a hydrolysis reaction.

answers: Charles-Louis de Secondat, baron de Montesquieu
parts: Identify this political philosopher, who coined the idea of the “liberalism of fear,” in an essay of the same name, and further explored the political ramifications of cruelty in the 1984 book Ordinary Vices.

Rorty invokes Shklar’s definition in the context of this writer, who wrote about cruelty “from the outside.” This writer’s non-fiction work includes essays such as “Good Bad Books” and a semi-autobiographical book that includes photographs of Welsh coal miners.

Shklar wrote a classic introduction to the thought of this philosopher, who satirised Christian society through the eyes of Uzbek and Rica in his Persian Letters and also wrote The Spirit of the Laws.
Name this author whose use of the word "hummy" elicited the line "Tonstant Weader Fwowed up" from a New Yorker book review.

This author savaged A. A. Milne in her "Constant Reader" book reviews. This woman known for her bon mots wrote about Hazel Morse's attempted suicide in "Big Blonde” and quipped “You might as well live” in “Resume.”
Dorothy Parker was a member of this "Vicious Circle" of New York wits also including George S. Kaufman and Robert Benchley.

answers: Alexander II of Russia [prompt on Alexander]
parts: Name this ethnic group that was ethnically cleansed under the supervision of Dmitriy Milyutin. This people’s flag contains three crossed arrows of gold pointing to an arc of stars on a field of green.

This Tsar ordered the resettlement of Circassian lands with Kuban cossacks. This Tsar established the zemstvo system but died before he could implement the constitutional initiatives of Count Loris Melikov.
Many Circassians refuse to eat fish in memory of their ancestors who died during their forced crossing of this sea from the Caucasus into Anatolia.
Name this Chinese creator goddess, the wife and sister of Fuxi (“FOO-shee”). This goddess also helped to repair the Pillar of Heaven by replacing the four columns holding up the sky.

Nüwa replaced those columns with the legs of one of these animals named Ao, which resides in the Bohai Sea with islands on his back. The “world” example of these animals is often depicted carrying the world, and in some myths an elephant.

In the Legend of the White Snake, this figure sells immortality pills to an unsuspecting boy named Xu Xian (“SHU SHEE-an”), but his main vocation was poetry. This figure was a real Tang Dynasty scholar but was later elevated to divine status.
Name this poet who wrote about Alpha, Beta, Gamma, and Delta in The Captive Mind, which attempts to explain why Stalinism appeals to intellectuals.
Miłosz hails from this Eastern European country. The author of Quo Vadis, Henryk Sinkiewicz (“shen-KYEY-vitch”), is from here.
This Irish poet, who wrote about seeing creatures “poised like mud grenades” that created “warm thick slobber” in one work, was heavily influenced by Miłosz and read a poem at his funeral.

answers: helium OR neon [or He OR Ne]
parts: Name this process in which a photon interacts with an excited electron to produce another photon with the same phase and frequency. It generates most of the light output by lasers and is contrasted with spontaneous emission.

Laser scanners in supermarkets typically used a mixture of two gases as the gain medium to produce a red beam. Name either of those two gases, which were also used to create the first gas laser of any wavelength.

The first wideband tunable lasers were this type, which use dissolved organic molecules such as Rhodamine 6G as the gain medium. Though largely replaced by solid-state lasers, they are still used in spectroscopy.

bonuses.leadin: The highest-ranking Buddhist cleric in this country is the Jebtsundamba (“TCHAWT-sun-DAWM-buh”). For 10 points each:
answers: Khorloogiin Choibalsan [10 A Buddhist revival has grown in Mongolia since the 1990 revolution focused at Sükhbaatar Square in this capital, whose name literally means “Red Hero.” ANSWER: Ulaanbaatar
parts: Name this country where Baron Roman Ungern von Sternberg propped up the government of the eighth Jebtsundamba, Bogd Khan.

Once the Red Army toppled Ungern von Sternberg, this early Mongolian leader liquidated Mongolian Buddhist institutions and clergy after pushing out Peljidiin Genden, who had denied Stalin’s requests to do so.
